title: 108_s2981
content: The Act titled "Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It includes findings and the sense of Congress. The Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004 includes findings on the global proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, and tactical missile systems posing a direct threat to national security. Terrorist and insurgent groups using these weapons hinder peace efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan. The proliferation of tactical missile systems threatens international peace and security. The Government Accountability Office estimates 500,000 to 750,000 MANPADS worldwide. Many countries with these weapons no longer need them. The Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004 highlights the global proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, and tactical missile systems posing a direct threat to national security. The United States should assist countries in securing, removing, or eliminating these weapons to prevent proliferation. The Department of State has not used funds to eliminate tactical missile systems since 2002. The Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004 emphasizes the global proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, and tactical missile systems as a threat to national security. The United States Government should prioritize combating the illicit trade of these weapons within its nonproliferation strategy. The Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004 aims to assist other countries in safeguarding or eliminating stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems to prevent proliferation. The Secretary of State is authorized to implement a global program to secure, remove, or eliminate stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. This program may include activities such as humanitarian demining, destruction of small arms and light weapons, and assistance in safe handling and storage of these weapons. Cooperative programs with international organizations to assist countries in safe handling and storage of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems, utilization of funds for elimination or safeguarding of these weapons, and management of these weapons at locations where US funds have been used for security. Actions to ensure equipment and funds for security upgrades at storage locations. The Secretary of State determines proliferation threats posed by certain systems and equipment, ensuring they are used for authorized purposes. SEC. 5. OFFICE OF CONVENTIONAL ARMS THREAT REDUCTION. An Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction is established within the Department of State to formulate policy and administer programs for reducing conventional arms threats. SEC. 6. REPORT ON CONVENTIONAL ARMS THREAT REDUCTION. The Secretary of State must submit a report on conventional arms threat reduction to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act. The report will detail past Department of State efforts, progress in establishing the Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction, and country-specific implementation of a global strategy for eliminating or safeguarding conventional weapons. The report required under this Act must detail the prioritization of elimination and safeguarding efforts for weapons, evaluation of integration with other US programs, and description of programs related to tactical missile systems. The report will be in unclassified form but may contain a classified annex. SEC. 7. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 authorized for the President in fiscal year 2005 under this Act, with a limitation of $10,000,000 until the Secretary of State submits a required report. In this Act, the term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund" refers to a fund established under a specific section of another Act. The term "small arms and light weapons" includes various types of firearms and weapons. The curr_chunk mentions various weapons such as recoilless rifles, missiles, rocket systems, mortars, ammunition, grenades, landmines, and explosives.
